fullText: Pass Over is a play that knows exactly what it is: a righteous yell of pain and defiance that doesn't bother to modulate its voice for white comfort.
dtliExcerpt: Pass Over is a play that knows exactly what it is: a righteous yell of pain and defiance that doesn't bother to modulate its voice for white comfort.
bwwExcerpt: In rewriting for Broadway, [Nwandu] has gone even further. Not only has she decided to push the play past tragedy into something else, but she has also, in its last 10 minutes, let its innate surrealism fully flower in a daring and self-consciously theatrical way. (The transformation is gorgeously rendered in Wilson Chin's scenic design, Marcus Doshi's lighting, Justin Ellington's sound and even, in their removal, Sarafina Bush's costumes.) Somehow Nwandu gives us the recognition of horror that has informed drama since the Greeks while also providing the relief of joy - however irrational - that calls to mind the ecstasies of gospel, splatter flicks and classic musicals, all of which are sampled.
